<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/compromised-cloud-compute-credentials';
	}
</script>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Dror Alon"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>

<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Cloud-21-illustration_orange.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Compromised Cloud Compute Credentials: Case Studies From the Wild","name":"Compromised Cloud Compute Credentials: Case Studies From the Wild","description":"A walk-through of attacks in the wild that abuse stolen cloud compute credentials in the cloud environment. Unit 42 researchers highlight two case studies.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/compromised-cloud-compute-credentials\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/compromised-cloud-compute-credentials\/","datePublished":"December 8, 2022","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nCloud breaches often stem from misconfigured storage services or exposed credentials. A growing trend of attacks specifically targets cloud compute services to steal associated credentials and illicitly gain access to cloud infrastructure. These attacks could cost targeted organizations both in terms of unexpected charges for extra cloud resources added by the threat actor, as well as time required to remediate the damage.\r\n\r\nThis blog highlights two examples of cloud compute credentials attacks in the wild. While the initial access phase is important, we will focus on the post-breach actions executed during the attack, and share the flow of these two attacks against the cloud infrastructure. The attack flows show how threat actors abuse stolen compute credentials to pursue a variety of attack vectors (such as cryptomining, data theft, etc.) and abuse cloud services in unexpected ways.\r\n\r\nTo detect the attacks described below, cloud logging and monitoring best practices as outlined by Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Cloud are essential, as they provide visibility into activity at the cloud infrastructure level. This emphasizes how important it is to follow Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud logging and monitoring best practices.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks helps organizations address security issues in the cloud with Cortex XDR for cloud, which detects cloud attacks such as cloud compute credentials theft and Prisma Cloud, which manages identity entitlement with least privilege entitlements.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nCloud, phishing, cloud security, coin miner\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nKey Principle of Working in the Cloud\r\nBefore diving in, we should understand a very basic and important rule of working in the cloud. An entity, whether a human or a compute workload, needs legitimate and associated credentials to access a cloud environment at the infrastructure level. The credentials are used for authentication (to verify the entity\u2019s identity) and authorization (to verify what the entity is allowed to do).\r\n\r\nAs a best practice, when a compute workload executes API calls in the cloud (e.g., to query a storage service), the workload\u2019s associated credentials should be dedicated only to it. They should also be used only by that workload or human, and not by anyone else.\r\n\r\nAs we will see in both examples, an important security principle that can help reduce risk in cloud compute credentials attacks is least privilege access. In particular, this means that the privileges associated with those credentials should be scoped down to the minimum set actually required by the code using them.This limits the actions an attacker can take when compute credentials are stolen.\r\nAttack Case 1: Compromised AWS Lambda Credentials Led to Phishing Attack\r\nAn attacker was able to execute API calls on the behalf of the Lambda function by stealing the Lambda\u2019s credentials. This allowed the attacker to execute multiple API calls and enumerate different services in the cloud environment, as shown in Figure 1. While most of these API calls were not allowed due to lack of privileges, the attack resulted in a phishing attack launched from a AWS Simple Email Service (SES) that the threat actor created.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_125983\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. An attacker enumerating the cloud environment using a compromised Lambda function\u2019s credentials.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis phishing attack not only resulted in unexpected costs for the organization, it also exposed other organizations to extra risk as well.\r\n\r\nWhile the outcome of this attack caused substantial impact, it could have been greater. In this case the victim didn\u2019t have an active SES, but if they had, the attacker could have abused it to launch an attack on the victim\u2019s organization or they could even have used a legitimate email account for the phishing attack.\r\n\r\nDue to the variety of cloud services used by organizations, it can be difficult to predict where a cloud attack will end. Going from cloud to phishing was not necessarily an expected path.\r\nAttack Flow\r\nAn attacker was able to exfiltrate the Lambda\u2019s environment variables and export them into their attacking machine (AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, AWS_SESSION_TOKEN).\r\n\r\nAs the credentials were exfiltrated, the attack was launched with the following steps:\r\n&gt; WHOAMI - 2022-05-20T20:35:49 UTC\r\nThe attack started with the GetCallerIdentity command. This command is equivalent to whoami, as it provides information about the entity the credentials are associated with. From the response, the attacker can gain additional information such as the account ID and the credentials type that was stolen. They cannot, however, determine anything about the privileges associated with the identity.\r\n&gt; Identify and Access Management (IAM) Enumeration - 2022-05-20T20:35:55 UTC\r\nThe next phase of the attack was an identity and access management (IAM) enumeration. IAM is considered to be a crown jewel for an attack. By gaining access to IAM, an attacker can elevate permissions and gain persistence on the victim\u2019s account.\r\n\r\nThe IAM enumeration included two API calls, which were denied due to lack of permissions:\r\n\r\n \tListAttachedRolePolicies\r\n \tListRolePolicies\r\n\r\nIt is fair to assume that the attacker noticed the lack of permission and therefore terminated the IAM enumeration after only two commands (possibly to avoid making unnecessary noise).\r\n&gt; General Enumeration 2022-05-20T20:39:59 UTC\r\nAfter failing to enumerate IAM, the attacker started an enumeration on different services in different regions. This technique is much noisier as the attacker is trying to learn the architecture of the targeted account and, more importantly, gain access to sensitive information that could exist in the cloud account.\r\n\r\nSome of the main services and API calls that were executed were:\r\n\r\nStorage Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tListBuckets\r\n \tGetBucketCors\r\n \tGetBucketInventoryConfiguration\r\n \tGetBucketPublicAccessBlock\r\n \tGetBucketMetricsConfiguration\r\n \tGetBucketPolicy\r\n \tGetBucketTagging\r\n\r\nEC2 Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tGetConsoleScreenshot\r\n \tGetLaunchTemplateData\r\n \tDescribeInstanceTypes\r\n \tDescribeBundleTasks\r\n \tDescribeInstanceAttribute\r\n \tDescribeReplaceRootVolumeTasks\r\n\r\nNetwork Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tDescribeCarrierGateways\r\n \tDescribeVpcEndpointConnectionNotifications\r\n \tDescribeTransitGatewayMulticastDomains\r\n \tDescribeClientVpnRoutes\r\n \tDescribeDhcpOptions\r\n \tGetTransitGatewayRouteTableAssociations\r\n\r\nLogging Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tGetQueryResults\r\n \tGetBucketLogging\r\n \tGetLogRecord\r\n \tGetFlowLogsIntegrationTemplate\r\n \tDescribeLogGroups\r\n \tDescribeLogStreams\r\n \tDescribeFlowLogs\r\n \tDescribeSubscriptionFilters\r\n \tListTagsLogGroup\r\n\r\nBackup Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tGetPasswordData\r\n \tGetEbsEncryptionByDefault\r\n \tGetEbsDefaultKmsKeyId\r\n \tGetBucketReplication\r\n \tDescribeVolumes\r\n \tDescribeVolumesModifications\r\n \tDescribeSnapshotAttribute\r\n \tDescribeSnapshotTierStatus\r\n \tDescribeImages\r\n\r\nSES Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tGetAccount\r\n \tListIdentities\r\n\r\nGeneral Enumeration\r\n\r\n \tDescribeRegions\r\n \tDescribeAvailabilityZones\r\n \tDescribeAccountAttributes\r\n\r\n&gt; Backdoor 2022-05-20T20:43:22 UTC\r\nWhile failing to enumerate IAM, the attacker tried (unsuccessfully) to create a new user by executing the CreateUser command.\r\n &gt; From the Cloud to a Phishing Attack 2022-05-20T20:44:40 UTC\r\nAs most of the API calls during the enumeration resulted in permission denied, the attacker was able to successfully enumerate SES. Therefore, the attacker launched a phishing attack by abusing the cloud email service, which included executing commands such as VerifyEmailIdentity and UpdateAccountSendingEnabled.\r\n &gt; Defense Evasion 2022-05-20T23:07:06 UTC\r\nFinally, the attacker tried to hide some of his activities by deleting the SES identity by executing the DeleteIdentity command.\r\nAdditional Insights for Detection\r\nA very important indicator of compromise (IoC) for this attack was the IP address 50.82.94[.]112.\r\n\r\nAPI calls from the Lambda function are typically executed from its IP with the credentials (including AccessKeyId) that were generated for the Lambda. Therefore, every API call with that AccessKeyId is considered to be the Lambda function. However, during the attack, the threat actor was able to steal the Lambda's credentials, allowing the attacker to impersonate it.\r\n\r\nBecause of this, the IP is the key IoC as it is the way to detect that this is not the Lambda. The attacker was using the stolen credentials to impersonate and execute API calls on behalf of the Lambda function, but they were doing so from an IP address that wasn't attached to the Lambda, nor did it belong to the cloud environment.\r\nAttack Case 2: A Compromised Google Cloud App Engine Service Account Deploying Cryptomining Instances\r\nAn attacker was able to steal the credentials for a Google Cloud App Engine service account (SA). There are many ways that attackers can accomplish this that are not necessarily related to any vulnerability in the cloud service provider. In many cases, for example, users store credentials in insecure locations or use easily guessed or brute-forced passwords.\r\n\r\nIn this case, the stolen SA was the default SA, which had a highly privileged role (Project Editor). This allowed the threat actor to launch an attack that ended with the creation of multiple high-core CPU virtual machines (VMs) for cryptomining purposes, as shown in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_125985\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. An attacker abusing a compromised App Engine SA to allocate multiple cloud instances for mining.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhen the threat actor launched thousands of VMs in the victim\u2019s environment, it significantly increased their expected costs. Even if someone had noticed an attack like this in their environment after a short period of time, it would still have had a substantial cost impact.\r\nAttack Flow\r\nGoogle App Engine is a Google Cloud fully managed serverless platform, and the service account is the token. When the user creates an App Engine instance, the cloud provider creates a default SA and attaches it to the created App Engine.\r\n\r\nThis App Engine default SA has the editor role in the project. The editor role is highly privileged, which is a key factor the attacker took advantage of. This role allowed execution of high-privilege API calls, such as the following:\r\n\r\n \tCompute workload launch\r\n \tFirewall (FW) rule modification\r\n \tSA key creation\r\n\r\n&gt; Privilege Escalation 2022-06-16T12:21:17.624 UTC\r\nThe attack started with an attempt to escalate privileges. As mentioned above, by default the App Engine\u2019s SA has editor permissions on the project. With these permissions, the attacker tried to add the compute\/admin role by adding the following object into the IAM policy:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAs we can see, the appspot in the SA domain prefix indicates this SA belongs to an App Engine service.\r\n&gt; Allow Any\/Any 2022-06-16T12:21:29.406 UTC\r\nNext the attacker modified the FW rules on the project level. First, the attacker attempted to create a subnet (named default). Then, the attacker added the rule below into that subnet:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThis action furthers the attacker\u2019s goal of mining cryptocurrency. To enable unlimited cryptocurrency mining, the attacker removed any limitation on the networking level.\r\n\r\nIt is important to note the priority field. By setting this to zero, the attacker\u2019s rule is set to the highest priority, meaning it will take effect first in the order of the existing FW rules.\r\n&gt; An Army of Miners 2022-06-16T12:21:38.916 UTC\r\nOnce setup was complete, the main phase of the attack began, launching VMs in multiple regions.\r\n\r\nWhile the attacker could have created high CPU machines, in this case the attacker instead created a standard VM (e.g., n1-standard-2) equipped with four high performance GPUs (e.g., nvidia-tesla-p100):\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOverall, more than 1,600 VMs were created during this attack.\r\n&gt; Backdoor 2022-06-16T13:25:56.037 UTC\r\nThe attacker assumed the SA key used for the attack would be detected and revoked, and therefore created multiple SA keys (for later usage) by executing the google.iam.admin.v1.CreateServiceAccountKey API call.\r\nAdditional Insights for Detection\r\nAs in the first case we discussed, the IP is an important IoC. In this case, the attack was launched from multiple IPs (nine different IPs overall), some of which were active Tor exit nodes.\r\n\r\nAgain, we expect the App Engine\u2019s SA to be used from an IP within the cloud environment. It definitely should not be used from a Tor exit node.\r\n\r\nFirewall rule modification is a common and popular technique used in attacks like these. Many organizations enforce network traffic rules that deny access to active mining pools, so attackers must modify firewall rules to accomplish their goals.\r\n\r\nLastly, by editing a network named default, the attacker tried to avoid detection. Unless this option is disabled, by default each new project is created with a default network. It seems the attacker was trying to take advantage of this, thus avoiding having to create their own network.\r\nConclusion: Compute Token Theft Is a Growing Threat\r\nThe theft of a compute workload\u2019s token is the common denominator for both cases we\u2019ve discussed. While both examples above involve serverless services, this attack vector is relevant to all compute services.\r\n\r\nIt is important to emphasize that this type of attack could occur from different attack paths \u2013 including application vulnerabilities or zero-day exploits such as Log4Shell \u2013 not only from misconfigurations or poor cloud security posture management (CSPM).\r\n\r\nTo handle such attacks, cloud audit logs are essential, both for detection and for investigation and response (IR). Cloud audit monitoring is even more critical for serverless workloads where agents cannot be installed, thus making it harder to stop such attacks.\r\n\r\nLogging and monitoring best practices provided by AWS and Google Cloud give clear guidance for how to prevent such cases. The AWS GuardDuty service could also help with detecting and alerting on similar attacks, such as EC2 instance credentials used from another AWS account. An additional prevention method is to configure an interface endpoint policy for Lambda to limit the usage of Lambda only within a VPC.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protections from compute token theft with:\r\n\r\n \tCortex XDR for cloud, which provides SOC teams with a full incident story across the entire digital domain by integrating activity from cloud hosts, cloud traffic, and audit logs together with endpoint and network data.\r\n \tPrisma Cloud, which assists organizations in managing identity entitlement, addresses the security challenges of managing IAM in cloud environments. Prisma Cloud IAM security capabilities automatically calculate effective permissions across cloud service providers, detect overly permissive access, and suggest corrections to reach least privilege entitlements.\r\n\r\nFind out how you can protect your organization from cloud environment attacks with Unit 42 Cloud Incident Response services to investigate and respond to attacks and Cyber Risk Management Services to assess your security posture before an attack takes place.\r\n\r\nLearn How to Detect Cloud Threats at Ignite \u201922\r\nAttend the session \u201cUnearth advanced threats using your network and cloud data,\u201d at Palo Alto Networks Ignite \u201922, the security conference of the future, to find out how to detect compromised cloud compute tokens. Our researchers will show you how to investigate and respond to cloud attacks with a live demonstration. Register now!","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/04_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Dror Alon"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

#ffffff;--wp--preset--color--pale-pink: #f78da7;--wp--preset--color--vivid-red: #cf2e2e;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-orange: #ff6900;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-amber: #0693e3;--wp--preset--color--vivid-purple: #9b51e0;--wp--preset--gradient--vivid-cyan-blue-to-vivid-purple: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(6,147,227,1) 0%,rgb(155,81,224) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--light-green-cyan-to-vivid-green-cyan: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(122,220,180) 0%,rgb(0,208,130) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--luminous-vivid-amber-to-luminous-vivid-orange: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(252,185,0,1) 0%,rgba(255,105,0,1)     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-125981 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">
        <button class="btn__search" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#search" aria-label="search"><i class="ui ui-1"></i></button>
      </div>

      <div id="search" class="collapse d-sm-block col-sm-auto col-12 ml-auto order-3">
        <div class="pt-sm-0 pt-20 pb-sm-0 pb-40 mt-sm-0 mt-n30">
                      <input type="search" placeholder="Search Unit 42" id="innerSearch" class="header__search" value="" required aria-label="Inner Search">
                  </div>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none d-flex ml-auto align-items-center order-5">
        <button class="btn__menu rounded" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#navigation">Menu</button>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</header>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-121229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-121229"><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"><b style="color:#C84727">Under Attack?</b></a></li>
</ul>  </div>
</nav>
<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/compromised-cloud-compute-credentials/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-125981-_ctihxawsx473"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>Cloud breaches often stem from misconfigured storage services or exposed credentials. A growing trend of attacks specifically targets cloud compute services to steal associated credentials and illicitly gain access to cloud infrastructure. These attacks could cost targeted organizations both in terms of unexpected charges for extra cloud resources added by the threat actor, as well as time required to remediate the damage.</p>
<p>This blog highlights two examples of cloud compute credentials attacks in the wild. While the initial access phase is important, we will focus on the post-breach actions executed during the attack, and share the flow of these two attacks against the cloud infrastructure. The <a href="#post-125981-_fueofwtqb3rq">attack flows</a> show how threat actors abuse stolen compute credentials to pursue a variety of attack vectors (such as cryptomining, data theft, etc.) and abuse cloud services in unexpected ways.</p>
<p>To detect the attacks described below, cloud logging and monitoring best practices as outlined by Amazon Web Services (<a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/mt/aws-cloudtrail-best-practices/">AWS</a>) and <a href="https://cloud.google.com/logging/docs/audit/best-practices">Google Cloud</a> are essential, as they provide visibility into activity at the cloud infrastructure level. This emphasizes how important it is to follow Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud logging and monitoring best practices.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks helps organizations address security issues in the cloud with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud-detection-and-response">Cortex XDR for cloud</a>, which detects cloud attacks such as cloud compute credentials theft and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-admin/prisma-cloud-iam-security">Prisma Cloud</a>, which manages identity entitlement with least privilege entitlements.</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Related Unit 42 Topics</span></td>
<td><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud</a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">phishing</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cloud-security/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">cloud security</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/coin-miner/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">coin miner</span></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_y30knz3pj4k1"></a><strong>Key Principle of Working in the Cloud</strong></h2>
<p>Before diving in, we should understand a very basic and important rule of working in the cloud. An entity, whether a human or a <a href="https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/workload/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">compute workload</a>, needs legitimate and associated credentials to access a cloud environment at the infrastructure level. The credentials are used for authentication (to verify the entity’s identity) and authorization (to verify what the entity is allowed to do).</p>
<p>As a best practice, when a compute workload executes API calls in the cloud (e.g., to query a storage service), the workload’s associated credentials should be dedicated only to it. They should also be used only by that workload or human, and not by anyone else.</p>
<p>As we will see in both examples, an important security principle that can help reduce risk in cloud compute credentials attacks is <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-least-privilege-access" target="_blank" rel="noopener">least privilege access</a>. In particular, this means that the privileges associated with those credentials should be scoped down to the minimum set actually required by the code using them.This limits the actions an attacker can take when compute credentials are stolen.</p>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_kdq0vw6banab"></a><strong>Attack Case 1: Compromised AWS Lambda C</strong>redentials Led to Phishing Attack</h2>
<p>An attacker was able to execute API calls on the behalf of the <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/features/#:~:text=AWS%20Lambda%20is%20a%20serverless,cart%20on%20an%20ecommerce%20website." target="_blank" rel="noopener">Lambda</a> function by stealing the Lambda’s credentials. This allowed the attacker to execute multiple API calls and enumerate different services in the cloud environment, as shown in Figure 1. While most of these API calls were not allowed due to lack of privileges, the attack resulted in a phishing attack launched from a AWS Simple Email Service (SES) that the threat actor created.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125983" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125983" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-125983" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-23.png" alt="Image 1 is a screenshot of Amazon Web Services showing a branch diagram of an attacker impersonating a Lambda function by stealing the Lambda’s token inside the cloud environment." width="900" height="430" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125983" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. An attacker enumerating the cloud environment using a compromised Lambda function’s credentials.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This phishing attack not only resulted in unexpected costs for the organization, it also exposed other organizations to extra risk as well.</p>
<p>While the outcome of this attack caused substantial impact, it could have been greater. In this case the victim didn’t have an active SES, but if they had, the attacker could have abused it to launch an attack on the victim’s organization or they could even have used a legitimate email account for the phishing attack.</p>
<p>Due to the variety of cloud services used by organizations, it can be difficult to predict where a cloud attack will end. Going from cloud to phishing was not necessarily an expected path.</p>
<h3><a id="post-125981-_91kdvpm7d39x"></a>Attack Flow</h3>
<p>An attacker was able to exfiltrate the Lambda’s environment variables and export them into their attacking machine (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AWS_SESSION_TOKEN</span>).</p>
<p>As the credentials were exfiltrated, the attack was launched with the following steps:</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_682e3z1utb9k"></a>&gt; WHOAMI - 2022-05-20T20:35:49 UTC</h4>
<p>The attack started with the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetCallerIdentity</span> command. This command is equivalent to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">whoami</span>, as it provides information about the entity the credentials are associated with. From the response, the attacker can gain additional information such as the account ID and the credentials type that was stolen. They cannot, however, determine anything about the privileges associated with the identity.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_sofzszfb2yh"></a>&gt; Identify and Access Management (IAM) Enumeration - 2022-05-20T20:35:55 UTC</h4>
<p>The next phase of the attack was an identity and access management (IAM) enumeration. IAM is considered to be a crown jewel for an attack. By gaining access to IAM, an attacker can elevate permissions and gain persistence on the victim’s account.</p>
<p>The IAM enumeration included two API calls, which were denied due to lack of permissions:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ListAttachedRolePolicies</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ListRolePolicies</span></li>
</ul>
<p>It is fair to assume that the attacker noticed the lack of permission and therefore terminated the IAM enumeration after only two commands (possibly to avoid making unnecessary noise).</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_lfnmqg2a6dto"></a>&gt; General Enumeration 2022-05-20T20:39:59 UTC</h4>
<p>After failing to enumerate IAM, the attacker started an enumeration on different services in different regions. This technique is much noisier as the attacker is trying to learn the architecture of the targeted account and, more importantly, gain access to sensitive information that could exist in the cloud account.</p>
<p>Some of the main services and API calls that were executed were:</p>
<p>Storage Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ListBuckets</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketCors</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketInventoryConfiguration</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketPublicAccessBlock</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketMetricsConfiguration</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketPolicy</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketTagging</span></li>
</ul>
<p>EC2 Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetConsoleScreenshot</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetLaunchTemplateData</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeInstanceTypes</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeBundleTasks</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeInstanceAttribute</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeReplaceRootVolumeTasks</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Network Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeCarrierGateways</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeVpcEndpointConnectionNotifications</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeTransitGatewayMulticastDomains</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeClientVpnRoutes</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeDhcpOptions</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetTransitGatewayRouteTableAssociations</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Logging Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetQueryResults</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketLogging</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetLogRecord</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetFlowLogsIntegrationTemplate</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeLogGroups</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeLogStreams</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeFlowLogs</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeSubscriptionFilters</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ListTagsLogGroup</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Backup Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetPasswordData</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetEbsEncryptionByDefault</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetEbsDefaultKmsKeyId</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetBucketReplication</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeVolumes</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeVolumesModifications</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeSnapshotAttribute</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeSnapshotTierStatus</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeImages</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SES Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetAccount</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ListIdentities</span></li>
</ul>
<p>General Enumeration</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeRegions</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeAvailabilityZones</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DescribeAccountAttributes</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_p4os898sryc9"></a>&gt; Backdoor 2022-05-20T20:43:22 UTC</h4>
<p>While failing to enumerate IAM, the attacker tried (unsuccessfully) to create a new user by executing the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateUser</span> command.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_2kabprh4oucb"></a> &gt; From the Cloud to a Phishing Attack 2022-05-20T20:44:40 UTC</h4>
<p>As most of the API calls during the enumeration resulted in permission denied, the attacker was able to successfully enumerate SES. Therefore, the attacker launched a phishing attack by abusing the cloud email service, which included executing commands such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">VerifyEmailIdentity</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">UpdateAccountSendingEnabled</span>.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_6wwdteb23miz"></a> &gt; Defense Evasion 2022-05-20T23:07:06 UTC</h4>
<p>Finally, the attacker tried to hide some of his activities by deleting the SES identity by executing the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DeleteIdentity</span> command.</p>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_emto8wi8q984"></a>Additional Insights for Detection</h2>
<p>A very important indicator of compromise (IoC) for this attack was the IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">50.82.94[.]112</span>.</p>
<p>API calls from the Lambda function are typically executed from its IP with the credentials (including <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AccessKeyId</span>) that were generated for the Lambda. Therefore, every API call with that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AccessKeyId</span> is considered to be the Lambda function. However, during the attack, the threat actor was able to steal the Lambda's credentials, allowing the attacker to impersonate it.</p>
<p>Because of this, the IP is the key IoC as it is the way to detect that this is not the Lambda. The attacker was using the stolen credentials to impersonate and execute API calls on behalf of the Lambda function, but they were doing so from an IP address that wasn't attached to the Lambda, nor did it belong to the cloud environment.</p>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_fueofwtqb3rq"></a>Attack Case 2: A Compromised Google Cloud App Engine Service Account Deploying Cryptomining Instances</h2>
<p>An attacker was able to steal the credentials for a Google Cloud App Engine service account (SA). There are many ways that attackers can accomplish this that are not necessarily related to any vulnerability in the cloud service provider. In many cases, for example, users store credentials in insecure locations or use easily guessed or brute-forced passwords.</p>
<p>In this case, the stolen SA was the default SA, which had a highly privileged role (Project Editor). This allowed the threat actor to launch an attack that ended with the creation of multiple high-core CPU virtual machines (VMs) for cryptomining purposes, as shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_125985" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-125985" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-125985" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-24.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of an attacker using a compromised app engine service account to find multiple cloud instances to mine." width="900" height="380" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-125985" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. An attacker abusing a compromised App Engine SA to allocate multiple cloud instances for mining.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When the threat actor launched thousands of VMs in the victim’s environment, it significantly increased their expected costs. Even if someone had noticed an attack like this in their environment after a short period of time, it would still have had a substantial cost impact.</p>
<h3><a id="post-125981-_ko3kjuhn25q1"></a>Attack Flow</h3>
<p>Google App Engine is a Google Cloud fully managed serverless platform, and the service account is the token. When the user creates an App Engine instance, the cloud provider creates a default SA and attaches it to the created App Engine.</p>
<p>This App Engine default SA has the editor role in the project. The editor role is highly privileged, which is a key factor the attacker took advantage of. This role allowed execution of high-privilege API calls, such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Compute workload launch</li>
<li>Firewall (FW) rule modification</li>
<li>SA key creation</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_1dw3qmu9hdj3"></a>&gt; Privilege Escalation 2022-06-16T12:21:17.624 UTC</h4>
<p>The attack started with an attempt to escalate privileges. As mentioned above, by default the App Engine’s SA has editor permissions on the project. With these permissions, the attacker tried to add the compute/admin role by adding the following object into the IAM policy:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-125987" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-25.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of 3 lines of code where the threat actor adds an object into the IAM policy in order to add an admin role." width="900" height="93" /></p>
<p>As we can see, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">appspot</span> in the SA domain prefix indicates this SA belongs to an App Engine service.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_cb0grr8yo7ao"></a>&gt; Allow Any/Any 2022-06-16T12:21:29.406 UTC</h4>
<p>Next the attacker modified the FW rules on the project level. First, the attacker attempted to create a subnet (named default). Then, the attacker added the rule below into that subnet:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-125989" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-26.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of 12 lines of code where the threat actor has tried to create a subnet named “default” and is now adding a rule below that in the subnet to allow for cryptocurrency mining." width="900" height="263" /></p>
<p>This action furthers the attacker’s goal of <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/security-operations/stopping-cryptojacking-attacks-with-and-without-an-agent/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">mining cryptocurrency</a>. To enable unlimited cryptocurrency mining, the attacker removed any limitation on the networking level.</p>
<p>It is important to note the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">priority</span> field. By setting this to zero, the attacker’s rule is set to the highest priority, meaning it will take effect first in the order of the existing FW rules.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_azrwz5mav8oq"></a>&gt; An Army of Miners 2022-06-16T12:21:38.916 UTC</h4>
<p>Once setup was complete, the main phase of the attack began, launching VMs in multiple regions.</p>
<p>While the attacker could have created high CPU machines, in this case the attacker instead created a standard VM (e.g.,<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> n1-standard-2</span>) equipped with four high performance GPUs (e.g., <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nvidia-tesla-p100</span>):</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126002" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/image4-1.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of many lines of code demonstrating how the threat actor created standard virtual machines, creating more than 1,600 in total." width="800" height="688" /></p>
<p>Overall, more than 1,600 VMs were created during this attack.</p>
<h4><a id="post-125981-_52f6wuqi3uw"></a>&gt; Backdoor 2022-06-16T13:25:56.037 UTC</h4>
<p>The attacker assumed the SA key used for the attack would be detected and revoked, and therefore created multiple SA keys (for later usage) by executing the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google.iam.admin.v1.CreateServiceAccountKey</span> API call.</p>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_ik1jah897kge"></a>Additional Insights for Detection</h2>
<p>As in the first case we discussed, the IP is an important IoC. In this case, the attack was launched from multiple IPs (nine different IPs overall), some of which were active Tor exit nodes.</p>
<p>Again, we expect the App Engine’s SA to be used from an IP within the cloud environment. It definitely should not be used from a Tor exit node.</p>
<p>Firewall rule modification is a common and popular technique used in attacks like these. Many organizations enforce network traffic rules that deny access to active mining pools, so attackers must modify firewall rules to accomplish their goals.</p>
<p>Lastly, by editing a network named default, the attacker tried to avoid detection. Unless this option is disabled, by default each new project is created with a default network. It seems the attacker was trying to take advantage of this, thus avoiding having to create their own network.</p>
<h2><a id="post-125981-_2devri753gt5"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong>:<strong> Compute Token Theft</strong> Is a<strong> Growing Threat</strong></h2>
<p>The theft of a compute workload’s token is the common denominator for both cases we’ve discussed. While both examples above involve serverless services, this attack vector is relevant to all compute services.</p>
<p>It is important to emphasize that this type of attack could occur from different attack paths – including application vulnerabilities or zero-day exploits such as <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/log4shell" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Log4Shell</a> – not only from misconfigurations or poor cloud security posture management (CSPM).</p>
<p>To handle such attacks, cloud audit logs are essential, both for detection and for investigation and response (IR). Cloud audit monitoring is even more critical for serverless workloads where agents cannot be installed, thus making it harder to stop such attacks.</p>
<p>Logging and monitoring best practices provided by <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/mt/aws-cloudtrail-best-practices/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AWS</a> and <a href="https://cloud.google.com/logging/docs/audit/best-practices" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google Cloud</a> give clear guidance for how to prevent such cases. The AWS <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/guardduty/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GuardDuty</a> service could also help with detecting and alerting on similar attacks, such as <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2022/01/amazon-guardduty-ec2-instance-credentials-aws-account/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">EC2 instance credentials used from another AWS account</a>. An additional prevention method is to <a href="https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-vpc-endpoints.html#vpc-endpoint-policy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">configure an interface endpoint policy for Lambda</a> to limit the usage of Lambda only within a VPC.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from compute token theft with:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud-detection-and-response" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR for cloud</a>, which provides SOC teams with a full incident story across the entire digital domain by integrating activity from cloud hosts, cloud traffic, and audit logs together with endpoint and network data.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud/prisma-cloud-admin/prisma-cloud-iam-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud</a>, which assists organizations in managing identity entitlement, addresses the security challenges of managing IAM in cloud environments. Prisma Cloud IAM security capabilities automatically calculate effective permissions across cloud service providers, detect overly permissive access, and suggest corrections to reach least privilege entitlements.</li>
</ul>
<p>Find out how you can protect your organization from cloud environment attacks with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/cloud-incident-response-at-a-glance" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Cloud Incident Response</a> services to investigate and respond to attacks and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/assess" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Risk Management Services</a> to assess your security posture before an attack takes place.</p>
<p><strong>Learn How to Detect Cloud Threats at Ignite ’22</strong><br />
Attend the session “<a href="https://reg.paloaltonetworks.com/flow/paloaltonetworks/ignite22/sessioncatalog/page/view?search.sessiontracks=option_1662500129090&amp;_ga=2.42431329.511218743.1666629774-446934889.1594421039&amp;tab.day=20221214" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unearth advanced threats using your network and cloud data</a>,” at Palo Alto Networks Ignite ’22, the security conference of the future, to find out how to detect compromised cloud compute tokens. Our researchers will show you how to investigate and respond to cloud attacks with a live demonstration. <a href="https://reg.ignite.paloaltonetworks.com/flow/paloaltonetworks/ignite22/start/page/main" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Register now!</a></p>
      
              </div>

        <ul> 
                        <li>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/shinyhunters-ransomware-extortion/" role="link" title="article - table of contents" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:sidebar:related-articles:Bling Libra’s Tactical Evolution: The Threat Actor Group Behind ShinyHunters Ransomware">
                      Bling Libra’s Tactical Evolution: The Threat Actor Group Behind ShinyHunters Ransomware                  </a>
              </li>
                            <li>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/large-scale-cloud-extortion-operation/" role="link" title="article - table of contents" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:sidebar:related-articles:Leaked Environment Variables Allow Large-Scale Extortion Operation in Cloud Environments">
                      Leaked Environment Variables Allow Large-Scale Extortion Operation in Cloud Environments                  </a>
              </li>
                            <li>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/github-repo-artifacts-leak-tokens/" role="link" title="article - table of contents" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:sidebar:related-articles:ArtiPACKED: Hacking Giants Through a Race Condition in GitHub Actions Artifacts">
                      ArtiPACKED: Hacking Giants Through a Race Condition in GitHub Actions Artifacts                  </a>
              </li>
                      </ul>
      </div>
      </div> 
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
          <div class="pa related-threat">
    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Cloud Cybersecurity Research Resources</h2>

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Futuristic illustration with glowing neon lights and advanced technology motifs, depicting cloud computing and data flow through interconnected networks. The scene is highlighted by hovering digital clouds and dynamic, illuminated linear structures, set in a dramatic, blue and orange color scheme." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/03_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Muddled Libra’s Evolution to the Cloud:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/muddled-libra-evolution-to-cloud/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Muddled Libra’s Evolution to the Cloud">

                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Close-up side profile of a Black woman wearing glasses, focused intently on something out of frame." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-xz-utils-cve-2024-3094/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094)">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094)</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cve-2024-3094/" title="CVE-2024-3094" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):CVE-2024-3094">CVE-2024-3094</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/linux/" title="Linux" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):Linux">Linux</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/xz-utils/" title="XZ Utils" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):XZ Utils">XZ Utils</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">

                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Navigating the Cloud: Exploring Lateral Movement Techniques:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cloud-lateral-movement-techniques/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Navigating the Cloud: Exploring Lateral Movement Techniques">

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Dual Privilege Escalation Chain: Exploiting Monitoring and Service Mesh Configurations and Privileges in GKE to Gain Unauthorized Access in Kubernetes:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/google-kubernetes-engine-privilege-escalation-fluentbit-anthos/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="compromised-cloud-compute-credentials:related-resources:Dual Privilege Escalation Chain: Exploiting Monitoring and Service Mesh Configurations and Privileges in GKE to Gain Unauthorized Access in Kubernetes">
